CLAMAN: Should we sort of lessen what we have given to the oil companies over the years and switch it over to electric vehicles?

MUNGER: I don't think the big problem of America is the oil companies have been favored too much.

CLAMAN: You don't think that's a problem?

MUNGER: Yes, by and large. Exxon is a technical meritocracy which is a very creditable place. In other words, if more of America ran like Exxon, it would be a better country.

CLAMAN: Let's get to Keystone, then. The Keystone pipeline was rejected initially. Now the new proposal from Transcanada is going. You are both Nebraska residents -- you live in California now, Charlie, but you're from Nebraska. You are also business people. The new route and when we get more details we will know but would you be for the Keystone pipeline if it doesn't threaten the aquifer and it doesn't threaten the areas that are culturally sensitive and environmentally sensitive?

BUFFETT: I'm not an expert, but it generally sounds like it makes a lot of sense to me. Awful lot of pipelines running through the United States. Net, they have certainly been a huge plus for the country. I don't know all the details on it, but based on what I know, I would say that it makes sense.

CLAMAN: Were you then disappointed when Keystone was rejected, it could mean so many jobs?

BUFFETT: I don't think that issue is done with yet. The jobs aspect of it is not the big aspect. The real question is what it will do for the country over many years and what the drawbacks are. But you can build anything that will create jobs. That doesn't mean it is a good idea.

CLAMAN: Bill, you are invested in alternative energy and some of it a certain subsector of nuclear, but looking at natural gas, wow, it is so unbelievably inexpensive now and cleaner than oil, do you think this country should be converting to nat gas burning cars and trucks?

GATES: Well, natural gas, unfortunately, the energy density unless you take it to a very low temperature is much lower, so there's a lot of innovators looking at how can we do that better. There are ways of converting natural gas to liquids, but those factories are very expensive so people are going to try to innovate. There's such good news that we have inexpensive natural gas. It is the most natural that we get the benefit of that in the power generation sector as we're turning over our power plants, but because the price is so attractive on an equivalent energy basis there will be innovations that move it into parts of the transport sector, that's very exciting.

CLAMAN: Charlie, you said on stage this weekend we should not look for energy independence, we should use up the bad guys' energy --

MUNGER: Or the good guys, like Canada.

CLAMAN: Or the good guys but conserve our own.

MUNGER: Right. That to me is an obvious conclusion considering how precious this stuff is going to get. Trying to use our whole supply, our reserves as fast as possible is insane.

CLAMAN: But you could arguably stick it to certain Arab nations who despise the United States and they despise Israel and make life difficult for everybody by completely turning off the spigot and not use their oil and then you hit them financially, no?

MUNGER: My desire to do spiteful things to the Arab nations is zero. As long as they want to sell their oil, I'm delighted to see us buy it rather than use our own. I think that adults suffer now to be better off later. When you save your own oil, and buy the other fellows', that's what you're doing.

CLAMAN: You drove an electric car, you said the most recent BYD, do you own an electric car?

MUNGER: No.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Charlie?

MUNGER: A Mercedes.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Warren?

BUFFETT: Cadillac.

CLAMAN: Bill, what car do you usually use?

GATES: I have a Mercedes.

CLAMAN: Two Mercedes. Mercedes is buying advertising right now on Fox Business, so thank you very much, we hope.

[laughter]

CLAMAN: You both took swipes at business school this weekend which I thought was interesting. You don't think they are teaching the right things. Warren, you went to business school.

BUFFETT: Apparently.

CLAMAN: Columbia.

BUFFETT: And I had a fabulous teacher. I went there because -- two fabulous teachers. And I went there because two people that I really wanted to sit at their feet and I got a chance to do that.

CLAMAN: And you're generous to business schools. You host more than 40 of them every year --

BUFFETT: 48.

CLAMAN: 48, let them come here and take questions. That's certainly wonderful. What is it that business schools are doing wrong?

BUFFETT: Well, in the investment field I thought that over the last 40 or so years that most -- a great many business schools were teaching nonsense. But that doesn't mean they were in other aspects of other majors within the business schools.

CLAMAN: Bill, Charlie, would either of you make a decision to hire somebody based on whether the candidate had gone to business school? Bill?

GATES: Well, if they are a young person, that's a recent part of their resume, so it might give them some valuable skills. I don't think anybody is saying that business school doesn't have some merit to it. It's just the -- how you do investment valuation as they have tried to apply mathematical techniques, they have claimed more than they should for these techniques.

BUFFETT: I hired a young woman a couple years ago out of business school, and she would have been very good naturally, but I'm sure she was better because she'd gone to business school, but I didn't hire her for what she learned about investments in the business school.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: I said I thought the business schools were improving, which I think is true, including in the investment field, but they have a lot of room for it.

CLAMAN: The Buffett rule, that's getting so much attention. Charlie, what did you think when Warren pushed for the Buffett rule and has been quite vocal about it?

MUNGER: Well, it's caused me some lack of popularity at my country club, and I'm willing to bear it in order to participate in Berkshire. I think it's fine if the rich people pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: Warren, you know --

BUFFETT: I think it's fine if he pays more taxes too.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Do you see the other side of it that, oh, the wealthy are the ones who are paying the biggest amount of taxes and that a large percentage of people don't pay any taxes aside from sales taxes, etcetera? That whole argument.

BUFFETT: Well the etcetera is payroll taxes.

CLAMAN: Yes.

BUFFETT: Payroll taxes are $800 billion of a $2.3 trillion dono -- revenue thing. So payroll taxes are a huge element of our revenue base.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: Well, I don't like the idea that nobody but the rich should pay taxes, because the country can't work on taxes from the rich people. It won't produce enough. And it would have terrible economic effects.

So I don't like this politics of envy style of -- of discourse.

But I think the rich people should cheerfully pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: We already talked to Warren about the developments in Europe this morning, with France turning socialist with Francois Hollande, who's the Socialist president. The U.S. banks, Warren, you said were in a far, far better position. But both you and Charlie sat here a year ago on Fox Business and really were quite concerned about what would happen with Europe.

Can the European banks -- or at least some of them -- are they so weak that they can somehow systematically negatively affect U.S. banks or our banking system here, Charlie?

MUNGER: I don't think it will have that much effect on us. But I do think they still have a terrible problem.

CLAMAN: Warren?

BUFFET: Yes, I agree with that. But, obviously, it would have some effect, but as I say, I do not think our fate is in the hands of European banks. And I'd worry very much if I were.

CLAMAN: Well, they're all very cheap.

Are -- are you -- would you (INAUDIBLE)...

BUFFET: They're not -- they're not necessarily cheap.

CLAMAN: So you're not considering buying any?

BUFFET: I -- I -- there's not a European bank that I'm looking at.

CLAMAN: Not a European bank you're looking at. Internationally, by virtue of the fact that you're huge in insurance in this -- in this company, we cannot ignore the risk that is lurking out of Iran and its plans for nuclear dependence and -- and perhaps eventually dominance.

Are you writing -- are any of your insurance companies writing any policies related to that risk of Iran?

BUFFET: We exclude nuclear (INAUDIBLE). But that's been true generally for a long time. We exclude. And the nuclear risk is one that all the resources of the insurance industry can't handle. So it would be folly to write it, because people wouldn't get the protection they thought they were getting.

So nuclear is out of the question.

CLAMAN: Charlie, are you concerned about what is happening in Iran and -- and do you see an eventual military tension between U.S.- Iran or -- or Iran and Israel, which would eventually, perhaps, draw in the United States?

MUNGER: Well, I don't think I know much about how it's going to work. And I am deeply suspicious of other people who claim to know what's going to happen exactly.

I think the future is often very hard to know.

CLAMAN: Trans -- we already talked about TransCanada.

Let's -- let's just quickly move on to your -- your lifestyle.

What newspapers or Web sites do you guys read every morning?

We have a lot of viewers who asked about this.

Bill, every morning, what do you reach for?

GATES: Well, I read "New York Times," "Wall Street Journal." "The Economist" is sort of my regular weekly fare.

BUFFET: He -- he can give you last week's by memory. He -- he knows every word.

GATES: No, it's great, it's great to have something you read on a regular basis. And they do special sections.

CLAMAN: Charlie, what do you read?

MUNGER: Well, I agree with Bill. I think the best one publication I read is "The Economist."..

CLAMAN: (INAUDIBLE).

MUNGER: -- which is interesting.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I read that, but I -- I -- I read the local paper. I read the "FT." I read "The Wall Street Journal." I read "The New York Times" and I -- and I read "USA Today."

CLAMAN: What do you watch on TV?

People wanted to know that, aside from sports, because I know you're a big sports fan.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I watch sports and I watch the Sunday news shows and -- and...

CLAMAN: Is there one you prefer?

BUFFET: No, I...

CLAMAN: Do you try to (INAUDIBLE) all...

BUFFET: I watch them all.

CLAMAN: You watch them all?

BUFFET: I watch them all. And I -- I have them taped and (INAUDIBLE).

CLAMAN: Oh, so you are technical?

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: No, my wife does it.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: And -- oh, what else do I watch here?

CLAMAN: I mean is there a show you think out there is clever?

GATES: Well, Comedy Ctrl is clever.

BUFFET: Oh, of course.

CLAMAN: Yes.

GATES: It's certainly, in a political season, there's a lot to make fun of.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Speaking of which, one of our viewers, one of our, actually, our viewer Twitterers had asked, "Who do you think might be a good vice presidential candidate for Mitt Romney?"

Charlie?

MUNGER: I haven't the faintest idea. I have some people I don't think should qualify.

CLAMAN: Who?

MUNGER: Oh, I'm not going to say.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: I was hoping you'd ask him.

(LAUGHTER)

MUNGER: It would be a long list.

CLAMAN: Warren, what do you think?

BUFFET: I think he shouldn't -- I think he would -- I think, largely, he will. I think he should pick somebody who he thinks would be best qualified to serve as president of the United States if anything happened to him. And -- and though people don't vote for the vice presidential candidate very -- to any great degree, so he can afford himself the luxury of doing that. And I think that he probably is the kind of person that will.

CLAMAN: Here's another Twitter person who wanted to know, "What is the most significant motivator in your working life and how has that changed through the years?"

Bill?

GATES: Well, I've kind of shifted from the innovations at Microsoft, which are great digital empowerment things, to helping the poorest. And so figures like how many less children died this year than last year, you know, pretty exciting to see that we're getting that number down.

You know, there's still a lot of science (ph), but it's -- it's aimed at the poorest now.

CLAMAN: Warren, your biggest motivator?

BUFFET: Oh, I -- just -- just running Berkshire is -- it's -- it's fun every day. And it's a never finished painting. And it's always got enough twists and turns in it to make it interesting.

So I know -- I know I'll have -- you know, I could -- I could be my age and retire and I could spend all week planning my haircut, you know. And this is a lot more fun.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: I want to thank all of you, Bill Gates, Charlie Munger and Warren Buffet...

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you .

CLAMAN: -- for joining us exclusively together. It's always fascinating to hear your perspectives on so many things.

Thank you for being on Fox Business.

BUFFET: Thank you.

CLAMAN: Stuart, back to you in New York.

END

urn:contentItem:5JR9-RJ11-DY0W-40DR-00000-00Warren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - Interview2012-05-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:50ZLexisNexisWarren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - InterviewWalthamFULL TEXT

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Let's go to Liz Claman in Omaha with, I believe, Warren Buffet and company, right?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You bet, from Varney and company to Warren Buffet and company.

Thank you so much.

Varney, you've got to watch this, because we're going to talk about a lot of things that you and your viewers have talked about.

But first, we welcome Warren Buffet, the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway.

Thank you for being here.

WARREN BUFFET, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY: Thanks for having me.

CLAMAN: Hey, the markets are open and trading.

BUFFET: Good.

CLAMAN: Let's take a look because you said over the weekend -- and you rarely say this -- that Berkshire Hathaway's stock is undervalued. And as we look at how it's trading, it is up slightly, about .5 percent.

What do you think of that trade?

Do you think it would have been higher, lower?

BUFFET: Well, that doesn't change my conclusion, because of some half a percent. And, you know, I don't -- I have no idea whether Berkshire's stock will go up or down in the next week or month or year.

But in relation to the businesses we own, it -- it's attractive.

CLAMAN: One of the number one questions that came out this weekend -- it was interesting to me, because I've been coming six years and I have never heard so many people ask why isn't Berkshire paying a dividend. This at a time when the largest percentage of S&P 500 companies are now paying dividends. It's the first time in a long time that they are.

And then you have the fact that you own dividend paying stocks like Coca-Cola, American Express, Intel, which just raised its dividend this morning, by the way.

Why won't you pay a dividend to your shareholders?

BUFFET: Well, we think our shareholders, five years from now, will be wealthier, counting what they would get from the reinvestment of the dividend. We think they would be -- they'll be wealthier if we hold onto the money.

Now, we may be wrong in that, but historically we've been right. And if -- if we had paid a dividend over the years our shareholders would be considerably poorer than they -- 10 years ago. And as long as we -- I think we will have the opportunity to invest dollars, to create more than a dollar of present value, we'll retain the money. And when we don't think we can do that we'll either repurchase stock or pay dividends.

CLAMAN: Is there no way you will ever pay a dividend?

BUFFET: Oh, some day Berkshire will pay a dividend because it will get so large that it can't use the money, or all of the money that it earns, effectively.

But -- but we don't think we're at that point, although we're much closer to that point, obviously, than we were 20 years ago.

CLAMAN: I just mentioned that Coke pays a dividend. Speaking of Coke, the board is mulling a stock split.

Would you be for a stock split of Coca-Cola?

BUFFET: I'm -- I'm totally neutral on that. It's -- it's fine with me if they do and it's fine with me if they don't.

But it -- it won't make any difference to us in terms of the value of our Coca-Cola stock.

CLAMAN: OK. The succession plan was a very major focus here. And you said you'd be very clear about it. You do finally have one person in mind, with two back-ups. I got you to tell us yesterday that it was a he.

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: But it is a male?

BUFFET: It's a male.

CLAMAN: It is a male. OK. I talked to some shareholders who said it is becoming increasingly evident to them that it's Ajit Jain, who runs your insurance business. Keep going with the poker-faced one, because they say the insurance business is increasingly becoming the -- one of the major important factors, the most important factors for the future of Berkshire and the profits that it brings in.

BUFFET: Look, I would say this about the insurance business. It's been enormously important in getting us to where we are now. It's still enormously important. It's actually not as important relative to the entirety of Berkshire as it was 10 years ago. We've added more businesses away from insurance.

But insurance has driven us to where we are presently.

CLAMAN: And the culture, you said he understands the culture of Berkshire.

BUFFET: Oh, all three of the candidates understand the culture very well.

CLAMAN: All right. All three, but Ajit at the top?

BUFFET: Oh, I --

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: When -- when we put you on the board, you'll know.

CLAMAN: OK. All right. Only the board knows.

You also said about your successor that under your new successor, there will not be much of a derivatives book under Berkshire's umbrella.

Is that because you feel you really understand derivatives in a way that nobody else does or that they've become dangerous for Berkshire?

BUFFET: Oh, it -- it -- there isn't that much of a derivatives book right now, if you look at the total value of Berkshire. We've done very little in new revenues. But we have a few and one particularly good sized position in terms of our equity put situation. Only that's nothing compared to what we have in equities overall.

So it's not a big deal now. I would guess it would be a lesser deal. And -- and partly that's because the rule -- in fact, in a big way that's because the rules have been charged on derivatives. We would not have the derivatives position we have now if the rules had been the same five or 10 years ago in relation to posting of collateral. We think that -- that derivatives become much more dangerous for the individual enterprise when they're required to post collateral.

CLAMAN: OK. You're 81 years old. That's not any news to anybody. But the fact that you were diagnosed with Stage 1 prostate cancer gave some people a start. It is obviously non-aggressive. And you say it's a non- issue. And you won't miss a single day of work due to your treatment, which starts in, what, July?

BUFFET: Mid-July.

CLAMAN: Mid-July?

BUFFET: Yes. Um-hmm.

CLAMAN: You won't miss any work at all?

BUFFET: No. No. No. Maybe -- maybe 15 minutes a day, something like that.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: We can lose you for 15 minutes.

BUFFET: Well, I wish -- I wish that we couldn't, but the truth is you can't.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: But when you look at the -- the person who will eventually take over, have you begun to apprentice your successor?

BUFFET: My -- my successor doesn't need apprenticing. If they needed apprenticing, they wouldn't be the successor (INAUDIBLE) --

CLAMAN: They wouldn't be the one?

BUFFET: No. In fact, none of the three candidates would need apprenticing.

CLAMAN: In some of what you talked about, you talked about how great some businesses are, but you talked about a big mistake. Energy future --

(CROSSTALK)

CLAMAN: -- from a Texas utility company.

BUFFET: All mine do.

CLAMAN: So sorry to bring it up.

BUFFET: I did it by myself.

CLAMAN: But these were tied very tightly to the price of natural gas.

BUFFET: Absolutely.

CLAMAN: Which plummeted shortly after you bought it.

BUFFET: Right.

CLAMAN: How'd you get that so wrong?

BUFFET: It was easy. I'll probably be able to do it again.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: The -- it was -- it was -- it was just a case of not -- not cranking that into my decision, weighting it with the appropriate probability.

CLAMAN: But 2010, you had to do a $2 billion write up -- write-down; 2011, another $398 million write-down.

How much --

BUFFET: (INAUDIBLE) that total. But the total -- the total we put in was about $2 billion and -- and I think it's been written out of maybe $400 million or $500 million.

CLAMAN: Well, how much was it going to get?

BUFFET: Well, it can go all the way to zero.

CLAMAN: Do you think it will?

BUFFET: It -- it easily could.

CLAMAN: Who -- who sold you on this idea, gold (INAUDIBLE) --

BUFFET: Me. Me.

CLAMAN: Really?

BUFFET: No, no, no.

(CROSSTALK)

CLAMAN: Goldman Sachs?

BUFFET: No, I -- I have -- I have a real ability to pick these -- pick these out.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: OK.

One of the things you said that people sat on the edge of their seat, because they want to know what you're buying, more newspapers.

BUFFET: It's possible.

CLAMAN: Jimmy Kimmel told a joke at the Washington correspondents dinner. He said, what's black, white and red all over?

BUFFET: Yes, so I heard.

CLAMAN: Nothing.

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: Yet you're buying now?

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: And you said specifically local newspapers.

How about "The New York Times?"

Is that local enough?

BUFFET: Well, I -- if a -- I would have to say, if I could buy "The New York Times," I might buy it personally. I -- I don't know whether I'd buy it for Berkshire. But it's not for sale.

It's -- that's a very special case.

The newspapers that exist in communities where there's a strong sense of community and where the newspapers respond to that strong sense of community by -- by telling people a whole lot of things that they want to know about their own community that they can't find some place else, those newspapers will do OK. They'll still be in decline over time.

CLAMAN: But is it that you see that their value is relatively -- that their price is relatively cheap to earnings?

BUFFET: In some cases.

CLAMAN: Um-hmm.

BUFFET: In some cases. But the earnings are not going to -- the earnings are not going to go up. I mean you're looking -- and -- and they're probably going to go down in most -- in practically all cases.

So you have to buy them at a value, actually, that takes that into account.

CLAMAN: "The Washington Post," you stepped down from the board.

BUFFET: Right.

CLAMAN: But you still fully own your position?

BUFFET: We own every share we've ever owned.

CLAMAN: Even though it's off its 52 week highs.

Do you feel it's doing pretty well?

BUFFET: Well, it -- I don't know whether they've published their first quarter earnings yet or not. But -- but they have problems in two of their businesses, one in the education business and one in the newspaper. And -- and that's been reflected, I think, in the price.

But those two businesses are -- well, the newspaper is far tougher than it was five or 10 years ago. And the education business is tougher than it was about two years ago.

CLAMAN: What's interesting to people, though, when you say that you would buy more newspapers is at a time when everybody else is getting out, it seems like you and Rupert Murdoch are the only people getting into newspapers.

BUFFET: Yes, right. And he may not be quite as competitive for a while, either. So, no. But they are not a -- it's not an industry whose earnings are going to -- the earnings are going to just shrink in the newspaper business, as are the revenues. But not -- I don't necessarily think they'll shrink at a dramatic rate where you have a strong feeling of community and you have a newspaper that serves that community well.

CLAMAN: "The Washington Post" reported Friday and their revenue --

BUFFET: Did they?

OK.

CLAMAN: -- fell.

Yes, their revenue fell. Well, speaking of Rupert Murdoch, because I brought it up, hoc, is the head of News Corp, the parent of Fox Business.

BUFFET: Sure.

CLAMAN: You -- you made a little quip about our sister network, Fox. One shareholder questioned whether your personal politics --

BUFFET: Yes.

MUNGER: Of course it would be a better idea, of course it should be done. This is a competitive world, you do not want to send the brains back.

BUFFETT: What bill is talking about would increase employment in the United States.

CLAMAN: Brains. You bought some brains in China, Charlie. BYD, the electric car company, it is fun to see you two disagree on stage. You disagreed about the VAT tax. Charlie thinks we should have a VAT tax. Later, Warren, you told me you didn't think that was a good idea.

BUFFETT: Right.

CLAMAN: Going to electric vehicles, you feel, Charlie, that we should be giving government incentives and real carrots to inspire people to drive more electric vehicles; correct?

MUNGER: We already do. I have a niece and her husband who commute in Washington, D.C. and because they ride in a Prius, they get to use the fast lane. That's a huge incentive.

CLAMAN: There's an incentive.

MUNGER: There is a lot of incentive and there should be.

CLAMAN: Should it be, Warren, at the expense because the money has to come from somewhere, at big oil, which is well-established and is getting a lot of tax breaks?

BUFFETT: Charlie is the expert on this subject.

CLAMAN: Should we sort of lessen what we have given to the oil companies over the years and switch it over to electric vehicles?

MUNGER: I don't think the big problem of America is the oil companies have been favored too much.

CLAMAN: You don't think that's a problem?

MUNGER: Yes, by and large. Exxon is a technical meritocracy which is a very creditable place. In other words, if more of America ran like Exxon, it would be a better country.

CLAMAN: Let's get to Keystone, then. The Keystone pipeline was rejected initially. Now the new proposal from Transcanada is going. You are both Nebraska residents -- you live in California now, Charlie, but you're from Nebraska. You are also business people. The new route and when we get more details we will know but would you be for the Keystone pipeline if it doesn't threaten the aquifer and it doesn't threaten the areas that are culturally sensitive and environmentally sensitive?

BUFFETT: I'm not an expert, but it generally sounds like it makes a lot of sense to me. Awful lot of pipelines running through the United States. Net, they have certainly been a huge plus for the country. I don't know all the details on it, but based on what I know, I would say that it makes sense.

CLAMAN: Were you then disappointed when Keystone was rejected, it could mean so many jobs?

BUFFETT: I don't think that issue is done with yet. The jobs aspect of it is not the big aspect. The real question is what it will do for the country over many years and what the drawbacks are. But you can build anything that will create jobs. That doesn't mean it is a good idea.

CLAMAN: Bill, you are invested in alternative energy and some of it a certain subsector of nuclear, but looking at natural gas, wow, it is so unbelievably inexpensive now and cleaner than oil, do you think this country should be converting to nat gas burning cars and trucks?

GATES: Well, natural gas, unfortunately, the energy density unless you take it to a very low temperature is much lower, so there's a lot of innovators looking at how can we do that better. There are ways of converting natural gas to liquids, but those factories are very expensive so people are going to try to innovate. There's such good news that we have inexpensive natural gas. It is the most natural that we get the benefit of that in the power generation sector as we're turning over our power plants, but because the price is so attractive on an equivalent energy basis there will be innovations that move it into parts of the transport sector, that's very exciting.

CLAMAN: Charlie, you said on stage this weekend we should not look for energy independence, we should use up the bad guys' energy --

MUNGER: Or the good guys, like Canada.

CLAMAN: Or the good guys but conserve our own.

MUNGER: Right. That to me is an obvious conclusion considering how precious this stuff is going to get. Trying to use our whole supply, our reserves as fast as possible is insane.

CLAMAN: But you could arguably stick it to certain Arab nations who despise the United States and they despise Israel and make life difficult for everybody by completely turning off the spigot and not use their oil and then you hit them financially, no?

MUNGER: My desire to do spiteful things to the Arab nations is zero. As long as they want to sell their oil, I'm delighted to see us buy it rather than use our own. I think that adults suffer now to be better off later. When you save your own oil, and buy the other fellows', that's what you're doing.

CLAMAN: You drove an electric car, you said the most recent BYD, do you own an electric car?

MUNGER: No.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Charlie?

MUNGER: A Mercedes.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Warren?

BUFFETT: Cadillac.

CLAMAN: Bill, what car do you usually use?

GATES: I have a Mercedes.

CLAMAN: Two Mercedes. Mercedes is buying advertising right now on Fox Business, so thank you very much, we hope.

[laughter]

CLAMAN: You both took swipes at business school this weekend which I thought was interesting. You don't think they are teaching the right things. Warren, you went to business school.

BUFFETT: Apparently.

CLAMAN: Columbia.

BUFFETT: And I had a fabulous teacher. I went there because -- two fabulous teachers. And I went there because two people that I really wanted to sit at their feet and I got a chance to do that.

CLAMAN: And you're generous to business schools. You host more than 40 of them every year --

BUFFETT: 48.

CLAMAN: 48, let them come here and take questions. That's certainly wonderful. What is it that business schools are doing wrong?

BUFFETT: Well, in the investment field I thought that over the last 40 or so years that most -- a great many business schools were teaching nonsense. But that doesn't mean they were in other aspects of other majors within the business schools.

CLAMAN: Bill, Charlie, would either of you make a decision to hire somebody based on whether the candidate had gone to business school? Bill?

GATES: Well, if they are a young person, that's a recent part of their resume, so it might give them some valuable skills. I don't think anybody is saying that business school doesn't have some merit to it. It's just the -- how you do investment valuation as they have tried to apply mathematical techniques, they have claimed more than they should for these techniques.

BUFFETT: I hired a young woman a couple years ago out of business school, and she would have been very good naturally, but I'm sure she was better because she'd gone to business school, but I didn't hire her for what she learned about investments in the business school.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: I said I thought the business schools were improving, which I think is true, including in the investment field, but they have a lot of room for it.

CLAMAN: The Buffett rule, that's getting so much attention. Charlie, what did you think when Warren pushed for the Buffett rule and has been quite vocal about it?

MUNGER: Well, it's caused me some lack of popularity at my country club, and I'm willing to bear it in order to participate in Berkshire. I think it's fine if the rich people pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: Warren, you know --

BUFFETT: I think it's fine if he pays more taxes too.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Do you see the other side of it that, oh, the wealthy are the ones who are paying the biggest amount of taxes and that a large percentage of people don't pay any taxes aside from sales taxes, etcetera? That whole argument.

BUFFETT: Well the etcetera is payroll taxes.

CLAMAN: Yes.

BUFFETT: Payroll taxes are $800 billion of a $2.3 trillion dono -- revenue thing. So payroll taxes are a huge element of our revenue base.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: Well, I don't like the idea that nobody but the rich should pay taxes, because the country can't work on taxes from the rich people. It won't produce enough. And it would have terrible economic effects.

So I don't like this politics of envy style of -- of discourse.

But I think the rich people should cheerfully pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: We already talked to Warren about the developments in Europe this morning, with France turning socialist with Francois Hollande, who's the Socialist president. The U.S. banks, Warren, you said were in a far, far better position. But both you and Charlie sat here a year ago on Fox Business and really were quite concerned about what would happen with Europe.

Can the European banks -- or at least some of them -- are they so weak that they can somehow systematically negatively affect U.S. banks or our banking system here, Charlie?

MUNGER: I don't think it will have that much effect on us. But I do think they still have a terrible problem.

CLAMAN: Warren?

BUFFET: Yes, I agree with that. But, obviously, it would have some effect, but as I say, I do not think our fate is in the hands of European banks. And I'd worry very much if I were.

CLAMAN: Well, they're all very cheap.

Are -- are you -- would you (INAUDIBLE)...

BUFFET: They're not -- they're not necessarily cheap.

CLAMAN: So you're not considering buying any?

BUFFET: I -- I -- there's not a European bank that I'm looking at.

CLAMAN: Not a European bank you're looking at. Internationally, by virtue of the fact that you're huge in insurance in this -- in this company, we cannot ignore the risk that is lurking out of Iran and its plans for nuclear dependence and -- and perhaps eventually dominance.

Are you writing -- are any of your insurance companies writing any policies related to that risk of Iran?

BUFFET: We exclude nuclear (INAUDIBLE). But that's been true generally for a long time. We exclude. And the nuclear risk is one that all the resources of the insurance industry can't handle. So it would be folly to write it, because people wouldn't get the protection they thought they were getting.

So nuclear is out of the question.

CLAMAN: Charlie, are you concerned about what is happening in Iran and -- and do you see an eventual military tension between U.S.-Iran or -- or Iran and Israel, which would eventually, perhaps, draw in the United States?

MUNGER: Well, I don't think I know much about how it's going to work. And I am deeply suspicious of other people who claim to know what's going to happen exactly.

I think the future is often very hard to know.

CLAMAN: Trans -- we already talked about TransCanada.

Let's -- let's just quickly move on to your -- your lifestyle.

What newspapers or Web sites do you guys read every morning?

We have a lot of viewers who asked about this.

Bill, every morning, what do you reach for?

GATES: Well, I read "New York Times," "Wall Street Journal." "The Economist" is sort of my regular weekly fare.

BUFFET: He -- he can give you last week's by memory. He -- he knows every word.

GATES: No, it's great, it's great to have something you read on a regular basis. And they do special sections.

CLAMAN: Charlie, what do you read?

MUNGER: Well, I agree with Bill. I think the best one publication I read is "The Economist."..

CLAMAN: (INAUDIBLE).

MUNGER: -- which is interesting.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I read that, but I -- I -- I read the local paper. I read the "FT." I read "The Wall Street Journal." I read "The New York Times" and I -- and I read "USA Today."

CLAMAN: What do you watch on TV?

People wanted to know that, aside from sports, because I know you're a big sports fan.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I watch sports and I watch the Sunday news shows and -- and...

CLAMAN: Is there one you prefer?

BUFFET: No, I...

CLAMAN: Do you try to (INAUDIBLE) all...

BUFFET: I watch them all.

CLAMAN: You watch them all?

BUFFET: I watch them all. And I -- I have them taped and (INAUDIBLE).

CLAMAN: Oh, so you are technical?

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: No, my wife does it.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: And -- oh, what else do I watch here?

CLAMAN: I mean is there a show you think out there is clever?

GATES: Well, Comedy Ctrl is clever.

BUFFET: Oh, of course.

CLAMAN: Yes.

GATES: It's certainly, in a political season, there's a lot to make fun of.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Speaking of which, one of our viewers, one of our, actually, our viewer Twitterers had asked, "Who do you think might be a good vice presidential candidate for Mitt Romney?"

Charlie?

MUNGER: I haven't the faintest idea. I have some people I don't think should qualify.

CLAMAN: Who?

MUNGER: Oh, I'm not going to say.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: I was hoping you'd ask him.

(LAUGHTER)

MUNGER: It would be a long list.

CLAMAN: Warren, what do you think?

BUFFET: I think he shouldn't -- I think he would -- I think, largely, he will. I think he should pick somebody who he thinks would be best qualified to serve as president of the United States if anything happened to him. And -- and though people don't vote for the vice presidential candidate very -- to any great degree, so he can afford himself the luxury of doing that. And I think that he probably is the kind of person that will.

CLAMAN: Here's another Twitter person who wanted to know, "What is the most significant motivator in your working life and how has that changed through the years?"

Bill?

GATES: Well, I've kind of shifted from the innovations at Microsoft, which are great digital empowerment things, to helping the poorest. And so figures like how many less children died this year than last year, you know, pretty exciting to see that we're getting that number down.

You know, there's still a lot of science (ph), but it's -- it's aimed at the poorest now.

CLAMAN: Warren, your biggest motivator?

BUFFET: Oh, I -- just -- just running Berkshire is -- it's -- it's fun every day. And it's a never finished painting. And it's always got enough twists and turns in it to make it interesting.

So I know -- I know I'll have -- you know, I could -- I could be my age and retire and I could spend all week planning my haircut, you know. And this is a lot more fun.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: I want to thank all of you, Bill Gates, Charlie Munger and Warren Buffet...

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you .

CLAMAN: -- for joining us exclusively together. It's always fascinating to hear your perspectives on so many things.

Thank you for being on Fox Business.

BUFFET: Thank you.

CLAMAN: Stuart, back to you in New York.

END

urn:contentItem:55KG-MWV1-DYG3-125D-00000-00Warren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - Interview2012-05-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:50ZLexisNexisCNBC/DOW JONES BUSINESS VIDEO ANALYST INTERVIEW9:32 AM ESTWarren Buffett,Bill Gates,Charles MungerBUSINESS050701cb.y70Warren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - InterviewLiz Claman

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Let's go to Liz Claman in Omaha with, I believe, Warren Buffet and company, right?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You bet, from Varney and company to Warren Buffet and company.

Thank you so much.

Varney, you've got to watch this, because we're going to talk about a lot of things that you and your viewers have talked about.

But first, we welcome Warren Buffet, the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway.

Thank you for being here.

WARREN BUFFET, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY: Thanks for having me.

CLAMAN: Hey, the markets are open and trading.

BUFFET: Good.

CLAMAN: Let's take a look because you said over the weekend -- and you rarely say this -- that Berkshire Hathaway's stock is undervalued. And as we look at how it's trading, it is up slightly, about .5 percent.

What do you think of that trade?

Do you think it would have been higher, lower?

BUFFET: Well, that doesn't change my conclusion, because of some half a percent. And, you know, I don't -- I have no idea whether Berkshire's stock will go up or down in the next week or month or year.

But in relation to the businesses we own, it -- it's attractive.

CLAMAN: One of the number one questions that came out this weekend -- it was interesting to me, because I've been coming six years and I have never heard so many people ask why isn't Berkshire paying a dividend. This at a time when the largest percentage of S&P 500 companies are now paying dividends. It's the first time in a long time that they are.

And then you have the fact that you own dividend paying stocks like Coca-Cola, American Express, Intel, which just raised its dividend this morning, by the way.

Why won't you pay a dividend to your shareholders?

BUFFET: Well, we think our shareholders, five years from now, will be wealthier, counting what they would get from the reinvestment of the dividend. We think they would be -- they'll be wealthier if we hold onto the money.

Now, we may be wrong in that, but historically we've been right. And if -- if we had paid a dividend over the years our shareholders would be considerably poorer than they -- 10 years ago. And as long as we -- I think we will have the opportunity to invest dollars, to create more than a dollar of present value, we'll retain the money. And when we don't think we can do that we'll either repurchase stock or pay dividends.

CLAMAN: Is there no way you will ever pay a dividend?

BUFFET: Oh, some day Berkshire will pay a dividend because it will get so large that it can't use the money, or all of the money that it earns, effectively.

But -- but we don't think we're at that point, although we're much closer to that point, obviously, than we were 20 years ago.

CLAMAN: I just mentioned that Coke pays a dividend. Speaking of Coke, the board is mulling a stock split.

Would you be for a stock split of Coca-Cola?

BUFFET: I'm -- I'm totally neutral on that. It's -- it's fine with me if they do and it's fine with me if they don't.

But it -- it won't make any difference to us in terms of the value of our Coca-Cola stock.

CLAMAN: OK. The succession plan was a very major focus here. And you said you'd be very clear about it. You do finally have one person in mind, with two back-ups. I got you to tell us yesterday that it was a he.

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: But it is a male?

BUFFET: It's a male.

CLAMAN: It is a male. OK. I talked to some shareholders who said it is becoming increasingly evident to them that it's Ajit Jain, who runs your insurance business. Keep going with the poker-faced one, because they say the insurance business is increasingly becoming the -- one of the major important factors, the most important factors for the future of Berkshire and the profits that it brings in.

BUFFET: Look, I would say this about the insurance business. It's been enormously important in getting us to where we are now. It's still enormously important. It's actually not as important relative to the entirety of Berkshire as it was 10 years ago. We've added more businesses away from insurance.

But insurance has driven us to where we are presently.

CLAMAN: And the culture, you said he understands the culture of Berkshire.

BUFFET: Oh, all three of the candidates understand the culture very well.

CLAMAN: All right. All three, but Ajit at the top?

BUFFET: Oh, I --

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: When -- when we put you on the board, you'll know.

CLAMAN: OK. All right. Only the board knows.

You also said about your successor that under your new successor, there will not be much of a derivatives book under Berkshire's umbrella.

Is that because you feel you really understand derivatives in a way that nobody else does or that they've become dangerous for Berkshire?

BUFFET: Oh, it -- it -- there isn't that much of a derivatives book right now, if you look at the total value of Berkshire. We've done very little in new revenues. But we have a few and one particularly good sized position in terms of our equity put situation. Only that's nothing compared to what we have in equities overall.

So it's not a big deal now. I would guess it would be a lesser deal. And -- and partly that's because the rule -- in fact, in a big way that's because the rules have been charged on derivatives. We would not have the derivatives position we have now if the rules had been the same five or 10 years ago in relation to posting of collateral. We think that -- that derivatives become much more dangerous for the individual enterprise when they're required to post collateral.

CLAMAN: OK. You're 81 years old. That's not any news to anybody. But the fact that you were diagnosed with Stage 1 prostate cancer gave some people a start. It is obviously non-aggressive. And you say it's a non- issue. And you won't miss a single day of work due to your treatment, which starts in, what, July?

BUFFET: Mid-July.

CLAMAN: Mid-July?

BUFFET: Yes. Um-hmm.

CLAMAN: You won't miss any work at all?

BUFFET: No. No. No. Maybe -- maybe 15 minutes a day, something like that.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: We can lose you for 15 minutes.

BUFFET: Well, I wish -- I wish that we couldn't, but the truth is you can't.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: But when you look at the -- the person who will eventually take over, have you begun to apprentice your successor?

BUFFET: My -- my successor doesn't need apprenticing. If they needed apprenticing, they wouldn't be the successor (INAUDIBLE) --

CLAMAN: They wouldn't be the one?

BUFFET: No. In fact, none of the three candidates would need apprenticing.

CLAMAN: In some of what you talked about, you talked about how great some businesses are, but you talked about a big mistake. Energy future --

(CROSSTALK)

CLAMAN: -- from a Texas utility company.

BUFFET: All mine do.

CLAMAN: So sorry to bring it up.

BUFFET: I did it by myself.

CLAMAN: But these were tied very tightly to the price of natural gas.

BUFFET: Absolutely.

CLAMAN: Which plummeted shortly after you bought it.

BUFFET: Right.

CLAMAN: How'd you get that so wrong?

BUFFET: It was easy. I'll probably be able to do it again.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: The -- it was -- it was -- it was just a case of not -- not cranking that into my decision, weighting it with the appropriate probability.

CLAMAN: But 2010, you had to do a $2 billion write up -- write-down; 2011, another $398 million write-down.

How much --

BUFFET: (INAUDIBLE) that total. But the total -- the total we put in was about $2 billion and -- and I think it's been written out of maybe $400 million or $500 million.

CLAMAN: Well, how much was it going to get?

BUFFET: Well, it can go all the way to zero.

CLAMAN: Do you think it will?

BUFFET: It -- it easily could.

CLAMAN: Who -- who sold you on this idea, gold (INAUDIBLE) --

BUFFET: Me. Me.

CLAMAN: Really?

BUFFET: No, no, no.

(CROSSTALK)

CLAMAN: Goldman Sachs?

BUFFET: No, I -- I have -- I have a real ability to pick these -- pick these out.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: OK.

One of the things you said that people sat on the edge of their seat, because they want to know what you're buying, more newspapers.

BUFFET: It's possible.

CLAMAN: Jimmy Kimmel told a joke at the Washington correspondents dinner. He said, what's black, white and red all over?

BUFFET: Yes, so I heard.

CLAMAN: Nothing.

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: Yet you're buying now?

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: And you said specifically local newspapers.

How about "The New York Times?"

Is that local enough?

BUFFET: Well, I -- if a -- I would have to say, if I could buy "The New York Times," I might buy it personally. I -- I don't know whether I'd buy it for Berkshire. But it's not for sale.

It's -- that's a very special case.

The newspapers that exist in communities where there's a strong sense of community and where the newspapers respond to that strong sense of community by -- by telling people a whole lot of things that they want to know about their own community that they can't find some place else, those newspapers will do OK. They'll still be in decline over time.

CLAMAN: But is it that you see that their value is relatively -- that their price is relatively cheap to earnings?

BUFFET: In some cases.

CLAMAN: Um-hmm.

BUFFET: In some cases. But the earnings are not going to -- the earnings are not going to go up. I mean you're looking -- and -- and they're probably going to go down in most -- in practically all cases.

So you have to buy them at a value, actually, that takes that into account.

CLAMAN: "The Washington Post," you stepped down from the board.

BUFFET: Right.

CLAMAN: But you still fully own your position?

GATES: I think the closest thing to that is whether or not an engineer who is trained in the United States but is a foreign citizen, it should be easy for them and they should be allowed to be a taxpayer here or they should be forced to go back and the jobs around them created in another country. So the high-tech, high-skills immigration issue is one that definitely affects the job picture.

CLAMAN: Senator John Kerry has the Startup Visa Act which would if there's a foreigner give them a green card if they have enough investment, they start a business, and they would hire some people, is that something, Charlie, you think is a good idea?

MUNGER: Yes, but I think Bill's idea is a much bigger idea. I think we're out of our minds to send brilliant people back when they want to stay here.

BUFFETT: I feel stronger about that than I used to. I mean it is crazy.

MUNGER: -- could be stronger.

BUFFETT: It just makes no sense. Bill gave you the best answer you could have on it.

CLAMAN: Why then do we have it, we make it so difficult with the H1B visa, which is the issue, would you say if you had the opportunity, Bill, to have the president's ear on that issue, surely he knows?

GATES: There are various things that have not gotten through the Congress, you know, people want to make sure you're doing your best to hire American workers, and so there's a legitimate concern there. But there's a way to be more liberal on this without at all substituting for domestic labor -- labor that you might have used.

CLAMAN: You have a lot of people that are worried about -- they marry the issue of the border with Mexico with brilliant engineers who are coming from India and China. Is there a way to separate that? Would it be a better idea, Charlie?

MUNGER: Of course it would be a better idea, of course it should be done. This is a competitive world, you do not want to send the brains back.

BUFFETT: What bill is talking about would increase employment in the United States.

CLAMAN: Brains. You bought some brains in China, Charlie. BYD, the electric car company, it is fun to see you two disagree on stage. You disagreed about the VAT tax. Charlie thinks we should have a VAT tax. Later, Warren, you told me you didn't think that was a good idea.

BUFFETT: Right.

CLAMAN: Going to electric vehicles, you feel, Charlie, that we should be giving government incentives and real carrots to inspire people to drive more electric vehicles; correct?

MUNGER: We already do. I have a niece and her husband who commute in Washington, D.C. and because they ride in a Prius, they get to use the fast lane. That's a huge incentive.

CLAMAN: There's an incentive.

MUNGER: There is a lot of incentive and there should be.

CLAMAN: Should it be, Warren, at the expense because the money has to come from somewhere, at big oil, which is well-established and is getting a lot of tax breaks?

BUFFETT: Charlie is the expert on this subject.

CLAMAN: Should we sort of lessen what we have given to the oil companies over the years and switch it over to electric vehicles?

MUNGER: I don't think the big problem of America is the oil companies have been favored too much.

CLAMAN: You don't think that's a problem?

MUNGER: Yes, by and large. Exxon is a technical meritocracy which is a very creditable place. In other words, if more of America ran like Exxon, it would be a better country.

CLAMAN: Let's get to Keystone, then. The Keystone pipeline was rejected initially. Now the new proposal from Transcanada is going. You are both Nebraska residents -- you live in California now, Charlie, but you're from Nebraska. You are also business people. The new route and when we get more details we will know but would you be for the Keystone pipeline if it doesn't threaten the aquifer and it doesn't threaten the areas that are culturally sensitive and environmentally sensitive?

BUFFETT: I'm not an expert, but it generally sounds like it makes a lot of sense to me. Awful lot of pipelines running through the United States. Net, they have certainly been a huge plus for the country. I don't know all the details on it, but based on what I know, I would say that it makes sense.

CLAMAN: Were you then disappointed when Keystone was rejected, it could mean so many jobs?

BUFFETT: I don't think that issue is done with yet. The jobs aspect of it is not the big aspect. The real question is what it will do for the country over many years and what the drawbacks are. But you can build anything that will create jobs. That doesn't mean it is a good idea.

CLAMAN: Bill, you are invested in alternative energy and some of it a certain subsector of nuclear, but looking at natural gas, wow, it is so unbelievably inexpensive now and cleaner than oil, do you think this country should be converting to nat gas burning cars and trucks?

GATES: Well, natural gas, unfortunately, the energy density unless you take it to a very low temperature is much lower, so there's a lot of innovators looking at how can we do that better. There are ways of converting natural gas to liquids, but those factories are very expensive so people are going to try to innovate. There's such good news that we have inexpensive natural gas. It is the most natural that we get the benefit of that in the power generation sector as we're turning over our power plants, but because the price is so attractive on an equivalent energy basis there will be innovations that move it into parts of the transport sector, that's very exciting.

CLAMAN: Charlie, you said on stage this weekend we should not look for energy independence, we should use up the bad guys' energy --

MUNGER: Or the good guys, like Canada.

CLAMAN: Or the good guys but conserve our own.

MUNGER: Right. That to me is an obvious conclusion considering how precious this stuff is going to get. Trying to use our whole supply, our reserves as fast as possible is insane.

CLAMAN: But you could arguably stick it to certain Arab nations who despise the United States and they despise Israel and make life difficult for everybody by completely turning off the spigot and not use their oil and then you hit them financially, no?

MUNGER: My desire to do spiteful things to the Arab nations is zero. As long as they want to sell their oil, I'm delighted to see us buy it rather than use our own. I think that adults suffer now to be better off later. When you save your own oil, and buy the other fellows', that's what you're doing.

CLAMAN: You drove an electric car, you said the most recent BYD, do you own an electric car?

MUNGER: No.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Charlie?

MUNGER: A Mercedes.

CLAMAN: What do you drive, Warren?

BUFFETT: Cadillac.

CLAMAN: Bill, what car do you usually use?

GATES: I have a Mercedes.

CLAMAN: Two Mercedes. Mercedes is buying advertising right now on Fox Business, so thank you very much, we hope.

[laughter]

CLAMAN: You both took swipes at business school this weekend which I thought was interesting. You don't think they are teaching the right things. Warren, you went to business school.

BUFFETT: Apparently.

CLAMAN: Columbia.

BUFFETT: And I had a fabulous teacher. I went there because -- two fabulous teachers. And I went there because two people that I really wanted to sit at their feet and I got a chance to do that.

CLAMAN: And you're generous to business schools. You host more than 40 of them every year --

BUFFETT: 48.

CLAMAN: 48, let them come here and take questions. That's certainly wonderful. What is it that business schools are doing wrong?

BUFFETT: Well, in the investment field I thought that over the last 40 or so years that most -- a great many business schools were teaching nonsense. But that doesn't mean they were in other aspects of other majors within the business schools.

CLAMAN: Bill, Charlie, would either of you make a decision to hire somebody based on whether the candidate had gone to business school? Bill?

GATES: Well, if they are a young person, that's a recent part of their resume, so it might give them some valuable skills. I don't think anybody is saying that business school doesn't have some merit to it. It's just the -- how you do investment valuation as they have tried to apply mathematical techniques, they have claimed more than they should for these techniques.

BUFFETT: I hired a young woman a couple years ago out of business school, and she would have been very good naturally, but I'm sure she was better because she'd gone to business school, but I didn't hire her for what she learned about investments in the business school.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: I said I thought the business schools were improving, which I think is true, including in the investment field, but they have a lot of room for it.

CLAMAN: The Buffett rule, that's getting so much attention. Charlie, what did you think when Warren pushed for the Buffett rule and has been quite vocal about it?

MUNGER: Well, it's caused me some lack of popularity at my country club, and I'm willing to bear it in order to participate in Berkshire. I think it's fine if the rich people pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: Warren, you know --

BUFFETT: I think it's fine if he pays more taxes too.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Do you see the other side of it that, oh, the wealthy are the ones who are paying the biggest amount of taxes and that a large percentage of people don't pay any taxes aside from sales taxes, etcetera? That whole argument.

BUFFETT: Well the etcetera is payroll taxes.

CLAMAN: Yes.

BUFFETT: Payroll taxes are $800 billion of a $2.3 trillion dono -- revenue thing. So payroll taxes are a huge element of our revenue base.

CLAMAN: Charlie?

MUNGER: Well, I don't like the idea that nobody but the rich should pay taxes, because the country can't work on taxes from the rich people. It won't produce enough. And it would have terrible economic effects.

So I don't like this politics of envy style of -- of discourse.

But I think the rich people should cheerfully pay more taxes.

CLAMAN: We already talked to Warren about the developments in Europe this morning, with France turning socialist with Francois Hollande, who's the Socialist president. The U.S. banks, Warren, you said were in a far, far better position. But both you and Charlie sat here a year ago on Fox Business and really were quite concerned about what would happen with Europe.

Can the European banks -- or at least some of them -- are they so weak that they can somehow systematically negatively affect U.S. banks or our banking system here, Charlie?

MUNGER: I don't think it will have that much effect on us. But I do think they still have a terrible problem.

CLAMAN: Warren?

BUFFET: Yes, I agree with that. But, obviously, it would have some effect, but as I say, I do not think our fate is in the hands of European banks. And I'd worry very much if I were.

CLAMAN: Well, they're all very cheap.

Are -- are you -- would you (INAUDIBLE)...

BUFFET: They're not -- they're not necessarily cheap.

CLAMAN: So you're not considering buying any?

BUFFET: I -- I -- there's not a European bank that I'm looking at.

CLAMAN: Not a European bank you're looking at. Internationally, by virtue of the fact that you're huge in insurance in this -- in this company, we cannot ignore the risk that is lurking out of Iran and its plans for nuclear dependence and -- and perhaps eventually dominance.

Are you writing -- are any of your insurance companies writing any policies related to that risk of Iran?

BUFFET: We exclude nuclear (INAUDIBLE). But that's been true generally for a long time. We exclude. And the nuclear risk is one that all the resources of the insurance industry can't handle. So it would be folly to write it, because people wouldn't get the protection they thought they were getting.

So nuclear is out of the question.

CLAMAN: Charlie, are you concerned about what is happening in Iran and -- and do you see an eventual military tension between U.S.-Iran or -- or Iran and Israel, which would eventually, perhaps, draw in the United States?

MUNGER: Well, I don't think I know much about how it's going to work. And I am deeply suspicious of other people who claim to know what's going to happen exactly.

I think the future is often very hard to know.

CLAMAN: Trans -- we already talked about TransCanada.

Let's -- let's just quickly move on to your -- your lifestyle.

What newspapers or Web sites do you guys read every morning?

We have a lot of viewers who asked about this.

Bill, every morning, what do you reach for?

GATES: Well, I read "New York Times," "Wall Street Journal." "The Economist" is sort of my regular weekly fare.

BUFFET: He -- he can give you last week's by memory. He -- he knows every word.

GATES: No, it's great, it's great to have something you read on a regular basis. And they do special sections.

CLAMAN: Charlie, what do you read?

MUNGER: Well, I agree with Bill. I think the best one publication I read is "The Economist."..

CLAMAN: (INAUDIBLE).

MUNGER: -- which is interesting.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I read that, but I -- I -- I read the local paper. I read the "FT." I read "The Wall Street Journal." I read "The New York Times" and I -- and I read "USA Today."

CLAMAN: What do you watch on TV?

People wanted to know that, aside from sports, because I know you're a big sports fan.

BUFFET: Yes, well, I watch sports and I watch the Sunday news shows and -- and...

CLAMAN: Is there one you prefer?

BUFFET: No, I...

CLAMAN: Do you try to (INAUDIBLE) all...

BUFFET: I watch them all.

CLAMAN: You watch them all?

BUFFET: I watch them all. And I -- I have them taped and (INAUDIBLE).

CLAMAN: Oh, so you are technical?

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: No, my wife does it.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: And -- oh, what else do I watch here?

CLAMAN: I mean is there a show you think out there is clever?

GATES: Well, Comedy Ctrl is clever.

BUFFET: Oh, of course.

CLAMAN: Yes.

GATES: It's certainly, in a political season, there's a lot to make fun of.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: Speaking of which, one of our viewers, one of our, actually, our viewer Twitterers had asked, "Who do you think might be a good vice presidential candidate for Mitt Romney?"

Charlie?

MUNGER: I haven't the faintest idea. I have some people I don't think should qualify.

CLAMAN: Who?

MUNGER: Oh, I'm not going to say.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: I was hoping you'd ask him.

(LAUGHTER)

MUNGER: It would be a long list.

CLAMAN: Warren, what do you think?

BUFFET: I think he shouldn't -- I think he would -- I think, largely, he will. I think he should pick somebody who he thinks would be best qualified to serve as president of the United States if anything happened to him. And -- and though people don't vote for the vice presidential candidate very -- to any great degree, so he can afford himself the luxury of doing that. And I think that he probably is the kind of person that will.

CLAMAN: Here's another Twitter person who wanted to know, "What is the most significant motivator in your working life and how has that changed through the years?"

Bill?

GATES: Well, I've kind of shifted from the innovations at Microsoft, which are great digital empowerment things, to helping the poorest. And so figures like how many less children died this year than last year, you know, pretty exciting to see that we're getting that number down.

You know, there's still a lot of science (ph), but it's -- it's aimed at the poorest now.

CLAMAN: Warren, your biggest motivator?

BUFFET: Oh, I -- just -- just running Berkshire is -- it's -- it's fun every day. And it's a never finished painting. And it's always got enough twists and turns in it to make it interesting.

So I know -- I know I'll have -- you know, I could -- I could be my age and retire and I could spend all week planning my haircut, you know. And this is a lot more fun.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: I want to thank all of you, Bill Gates, Charlie Munger and Warren Buffet...

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Thank you .

CLAMAN: -- for joining us exclusively together. It's always fascinating to hear your perspectives on so many things.

Thank you for being on Fox Business.

BUFFET: Thank you.

CLAMAN: Stuart, back to you in New York.

urn:contentItem:55KG-Y2P1-F0HW-53P0-00000-00Warren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - Interview2012-05-07T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:43:50ZLexisNexisWarren Buffett/Bill Gates/Charles Munger - Interview

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: Let's go to Liz Claman in Omaha with, I believe, Warren Buffet and company, right?

LIZ CLAMAN, FBN CORRESPONDENT: You bet, from Varney and company to Warren Buffet and company.

Thank you so much.

Varney, you've got to watch this, because we're going to talk about a lot of things that you and your viewers have talked about.

But first, we welcome Warren Buffet, the chairman and CEO of Berkshire Hathaway.

Thank you for being here.

WARREN BUFFET, CHAIRMAN AND CEO, BERKSHIRE HATHAWAY: Thanks for having me.

CLAMAN: Hey, the markets are open and trading.

BUFFET: Good.

CLAMAN: Let's take a look because you said over the weekend -- and you rarely say this -- that Berkshire Hathaway's stock is undervalued. And as we look at how it's trading, it is up slightly, about .5 percent.

What do you think of that trade?

Do you think it would have been higher, lower?

BUFFET: Well, that doesn't change my conclusion, because of some half a percent. And, you know, I don't -- I have no idea whether Berkshire's stock will go up or down in the next week or month or year.

But in relation to the businesses we own, it -- it's attractive.

CLAMAN: One of the number one questions that came out this weekend -- it was interesting to me, because I've been coming six years and I have never heard so many people ask why isn't Berkshire paying a dividend. This at a time when the largest percentage of S&P 500 companies are now paying dividends. It's the first time in a long time that they are.

And then you have the fact that you own dividend paying stocks like Coca-Cola, American Express, Intel, which just raised its dividend this morning, by the way.

Why won't you pay a dividend to your shareholders?

BUFFET: Well, we think our shareholders, five years from now, will be wealthier, counting what they would get from the reinvestment of the dividend. We think they would be -- they'll be wealthier if we hold onto the money.

Now, we may be wrong in that, but historically we've been right. And if -- if we had paid a dividend over the years our shareholders would be considerably poorer than they -- 10 years ago. And as long as we -- I think we will have the opportunity to invest dollars, to create more than a dollar of present value, we'll retain the money. And when we don't think we can do that we'll either repurchase stock or pay dividends.

CLAMAN: Is there no way you will ever pay a dividend?

BUFFET: Oh, some day Berkshire will pay a dividend because it will get so large that it can't use the money, or all of the money that it earns, effectively.

But -- but we don't think we're at that point, although we're much closer to that point, obviously, than we were 20 years ago.

CLAMAN: I just mentioned that Coke pays a dividend. Speaking of Coke, the board is mulling a stock split.

Would you be for a stock split of Coca-Cola?

BUFFET: I'm -- I'm totally neutral on that. It's -- it's fine with me if they do and it's fine with me if they don't.

But it -- it won't make any difference to us in terms of the value of our Coca-Cola stock.

CLAMAN: OK. The succession plan was a very major focus here. And you said you'd be very clear about it. You do finally have one person in mind, with two back-ups. I got you to tell us yesterday that it was a he.

BUFFET: Yes.

CLAMAN: But it is a male?

BUFFET: It's a male.

CLAMAN: It is a male. OK. I talked to some shareholders who said it is becoming increasingly evident to them that it's Ajit Jain, who runs your insurance business. Keep going with the poker-faced one, because they say the insurance business is increasingly becoming the -- one of the major important factors, the most important factors for the future of Berkshire and the profits that it brings in.

BUFFET: Look, I would say this about the insurance business. It's been enormously important in getting us to where we are now. It's still enormously important. It's actually not as important relative to the entirety of Berkshire as it was 10 years ago. We've added more businesses away from insurance.

But insurance has driven us to where we are presently.

CLAMAN: And the culture, you said he understands the culture of Berkshire.

BUFFET: Oh, all three of the candidates understand the culture very well.

CLAMAN: All right. All three, but Ajit at the top?

BUFFET: Oh, I --

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: When -- when we put you on the board, you'll know.

CLAMAN: OK. All right. Only the board knows.

You also said about your successor that under your new successor, there will not be much of a derivatives book under Berkshire's umbrella.

Is that because you feel you really understand derivatives in a way that nobody else does or that they've become dangerous for Berkshire?

BUFFET: Oh, it -- it -- there isn't that much of a derivatives book right now, if you look at the total value of Berkshire. We've done very little in new revenues. But we have a few and one particularly good sized position in terms of our equity put situation. Only that's nothing compared to what we have in equities overall.

So it's not a big deal now. I would guess it would be a lesser deal. And -- and partly that's because the rule -- in fact, in a big way that's because the rules have been charged on derivatives. We would not have the derivatives position we have now if the rules had been the same five or 10 years ago in relation to posting of collateral. We think that -- that derivatives become much more dangerous for the individual enterprise when they're required to post collateral.

CLAMAN: OK. You're 81 years old. That's not any news to anybody. But the fact that you were diagnosed with Stage 1 prostate cancer gave some people a start. It is obviously non-aggressive. And you say it's a non- issue. And you won't miss a single day of work due to your treatment, which starts in, what, July?

BUFFET: Mid-July.

CLAMAN: Mid-July?

BUFFET: Yes. Um-hmm.

CLAMAN: You won't miss any work at all?

BUFFET: No. No. No. Maybe -- maybe 15 minutes a day, something like that.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: We can lose you for 15 minutes.

BUFFET: Well, I wish -- I wish that we couldn't, but the truth is you can't.

(LAUGHTER)

CLAMAN: But when you look at the -- the person who will eventually take over, have you begun to apprentice your successor?

BUFFET: My -- my successor doesn't need apprenticing. If they needed apprenticing, they wouldn't be the successor (INAUDIBLE) --

CLAMAN: They wouldn't be the one?

BUFFET: No. In fact, none of the three candidates would need apprenticing.

CLAMAN: In some of what you talked about, you talked about how great some businesses are, but you talked about a big mistake. Energy future --

(CROSSTALK)

CLAMAN: -- from a Texas utility company.

BUFFET: All mine do.

CLAMAN: So sorry to bring it up.

BUFFET: I did it by myself.

CLAMAN: But these were tied very tightly to the price of natural gas.

BUFFET: Absolutely.

CLAMAN: Which plummeted shortly after you bought it.

BUFFET: Right.

CLAMAN: How'd you get that so wrong?

BUFFET: It was easy. I'll probably be able to do it again.

(LAUGHTER)

BUFFET: The -- it was -- it was -- it was just a case of not -- not cranking that into my decision, weighting it with the appropriate probability.

CLAMAN: But 2010, you had to do a $2 billion write up -- write-down; 2011, another $398 million write-down.

How much --

BUFFET: (INAUDIBLE) that total. But the total -- the total we put in was about $2 billion and -- and I think it's been written out of maybe $400 million or $500 million.
